quantityRules.description: Ball pythons are solitary and do NOT tolerate cohabitation. House individually only - minimum 120 gallons (48Ã—24Ã—24 inches). Cohabitation causes stress, competition, disease transmission, and potential cannibalism.

careTargets.gradient: Horizontal thermal gradient required (88-92Â°F warm side â†’ 76-80Â°F cool side)

lifespan: 30+ years in captivity (commonly reach 40+ years with proper care)
temperament: Docile and calm, may ball up when stressed but rarely bites
originRegion: West and Central Africa (grasslands and forest edges)
setupTips: PVC or wood enclosures hold humidity better than glass tanks with screen tops
Multiple heating options work: UTHs, CHEs, DHPs, RHPs, or halogen flood lights - use thermostat with any heat source
Soil-based substrate (coconut husk, cypress mulch, organic topsoil, or ReptiSoil) holds humidity best - avoid aspen
Minimum of two hides required: one warm side, one cool side - identical hides preferred so snake doesn't prioritize security over temperature
Water bowl must be large enough for full-body soaking
Provide climbing opportunities - ball pythons are active semi-arboreal hunters in the wild and will utilize vertical space
Use thermostat to regulate all heat sources - unregulated UTH can reach 120Â°F+ and cause severe burns
notes: Over 6500 morphs available - huge variety in colors/patterns
Named 'ball python' because they curl into tight defensive ball with head protected in center when threatened - 'royal python' name comes from African rulers wearing them as jewelry
Wild ball pythons are specialist predators of African soft-furred rats (Praomys) - this prey preference explains their notorious 'picky eating' in captivity
Females provide parental care - coil around eggs for 55-60 days, shivering to generate heat and rotating eggs to maintain even temperature (one of few snake species showing maternal behavior)
Can sense infrared radiation through heat-sensitive pits along jaw - allows hunting in complete darkness by 'seeing' the body heat of prey

warnings.message: Proper temperature gradient is critical for digestion. Warm side 88-92Â°F, cool side 76-80Â°F. Temperatures below 88Â°F on warm side prevent proper digestion; above 95Â°F can cause injury with prolonged exposure. Temps below 75Â°F compromise immune system.

All heat sources MUST be regulated by thermostat. Unregulated UTH can reach 120Â°F+ causing severe burns. Choose heat source based on enclosure type: UTHs work for tubs/tanks/PVC, RHPs for solid-top cages, CHEs/DHPs for screen-top tanks, halogens for daytime heat + light.

Cohabitation is NOT recommended despite being commonly attempted. Causes chronic stress, competition for resources, disease transmission, cannibalism, and breeding complications. Ball pythons are solitaryâ€”house individually.

Ideal humidity is 70-80% (typical of African tropical savannas). Many sources say 60% is adequate, but 60% can cause dehydration in some individuals. Humidity below 60% causes bad sheds and respiratory infections. Above 80% with wet substrate surface can lead to scale rot.

Ball pythons fast seasonally (1-6 months normal if healthy weight). Monitor weight monthly. Seek vet if: weight loss >10%, visible ribs, lethargy, regurgitation, or refusal >6 months with declining body condition.

Minimum enclosure footprint: length equal to or greater than snake length, with 24+ inches depth. 4'Ã—2' footprint comfortably accommodates average adults. Larger is better if properly cluttered. Empty space causes stress, not enclosure size itself.

Obesity is the #1 health issue in captive ball pythons. Hatchlings: 10-15% every 7 days. Juveniles until weight plateaus: 7% every 14-20 days. Adults: 5% every 20-30 days OR 6% every 30-40 days. Weekly feeding in adults causes obesity.

feedingRequirements: Obligate carnivore - whole prey animals ONLY (rats, mice, ASF rats, quail, chicks)
VARIETY ESSENTIAL - rotate between rats (60-70% of diet), mice, ASF rats, quail, chicks (30-40%)
Frozen-thawed preferred over live prey (safer for snake, more humane)
10% body weight rule: Prey item(s) should total 10% of snake's weight
Prey size: No larger than 1.5x snake's girth at widest point
Thaw prey in warm water (100-110Â°F) for 20-60 minutes, never microwave
feedingSchedule: 0-12 months OR until snake reaches ~500g: 10-15% body weight every 7 days
12-24 months OR until weight remains consistent for 2 months: up to 7% body weight every 14-20 days
Adults: up to 5% body weight every 20-30 days, OR slightly larger meals (up to 6%) every 30-40 days
Body at healthy weight: softly rounded triangular shape, clearly defined neck, smooth taper from body to tail, feels muscular and strong
If body is more round than triangular: reduce prey weight and/or space out feedings more
If body is sharply triangular with prominent spine and straight/concave sides: increase prey size
Weigh snake monthly to adjust portions and monitor health
waterNotes: Large water bowl essential - must be large enough for snake to curl up inside completely
Water bowl placement: Cool side (prevents excessive evaporation)
Change water DAILY (ball pythons often defecate in water bowls)
Scrub bowl with reptile-safe disinfectant 2-3x weekly
Bowl depth: 2-3 inches minimum for soaking
Ball pythons soak 1-3 hours before shedding (normal behavior)
mistingNotes: Target humidity: 70-80% for optimal health (60% minimum, but some individuals may show dehydration at this level)
Primary humidity method: Pour 1-2 quarts of water directly into deep substrate (2-4 inches) for gradual evaporation - more effective than surface misting
Surface misting evaporates quickly causing humidity spikes that drop within hours - saturating substrate provides stable humidity
Keep hide areas dry to avoid scale rot while maintaining overall humidity
If struggling with humidity: reduce screen ventilation, use water-friendly substrate (coconut husk, cypress mulch, ReptiSoil), provide large water dish
Avoid foggers/misters that create constantly wet environment - can cause scale rot
